awd_titl_txt: Family Support of Math and Science: Examining an Untapped Source of Resilience for Diverse High School Students
awd_abstract_narration:
High school is a critical turning point in many students' STEM coursework and career trajectories. For example, students' math motivation peaks in high school yet 45% of 10th graders who express interest in pursuing a STEM career lose that interest by the end of high school. Adolescents with minimal math and science high school coursework are extremely unlikely to either try or be able to enter STEM college majors and careers.  To change these trends, it is necessary to understand how best to support high school students in math and science. Moreover, to increase the diversity of the nation's STEM workforce, it is important to understand whether motivational processes work differently for youth who reside at the intersections of demographic characteristics such as gender, race and social class. The current body of research on social factors that contribute to high school students' STEM motivation is largely based on studies of Caucasian families. This project exemplifies the Education and Human Resources Core Research program's commitment to fundamental research on learning in STEM that combines theory, techniques, and perspectives from a wide range of disciplines and contexts.  

Drawing from expectancy-value motivational theory, social positioning theories and feminist intersectionality theory, this project has five aims that center around understanding the role that parents play in students' STEM trajectories. Family support matters because it has been recognized as an important factor in maintaining student interest. To achieve its aims, the project team will analyze four waves of data from the High School Longitudinal Study (HSLS). The HSLS includes a nationally representative sample of 21,444 9th graders. It offers a large, rich sample to study intersectionality as defined by students' simultaneous status on multiple demographic indicators. The data includes longitudinal multi-reporter information on student motivation, outcomes, and parent support in math and science. Students' trajectories will be traced at 9th grade, 11th grade, the fall immediately after high school graduation, and 3 years after high school. The role of other socializing factors such as school and peer experiences are also examined.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
What motivates and sustains high school students? interest in STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math)? And do these key factors vary based on adolescents? gender, race/ethnicity, social class, and whether their parents went to college? The overarching goal of this NSF-funded project was to address these broad questions about what promotes motivation and persistence in STEM among diverse high school students. Empirical results on these topics are important because the loss of STEM talent from marginalized groups can have profound negative consequences for individuals' social mobility and the extent to which STEM can adequately address the needs and wellness of everyone in our diverse society. Because high school is a critical turning point in individuals? STEM pathways, the data used in this project come from the High School Longitudinal Study (HSLS)--a nationally representative sample of more than 20,000 9th graders in the U.S. with follow-up data collected at 11th grade and 3 years after high school. Below, we highlight some of our most relevant findings.

The first goal of the project was to understand the changes in adolescents? STEM motivation during high school. Much of the existing literature emphasizes the declines in students? motivation and focuses on each STEM domain separately. Our findings extend theory by demonstrating that the motivational beliefs of many students do not decline, and that students? math and science motivation positively influence each other over time. Across several papers, we found that a sizeable proportion of students held high motivational beliefs in both math and science throughout high school and other students experienced increases in their motivational beliefs, including students who developed aspirations for STEM careers during high school. These findings are important as they challenge common narratives about the need to stop the leaky STEM in high school. Though some students are turning away from STEM, there are also other students who maintain their STEM motivation and aspirations and, importantly, students who become more interested in and identify with STEM during high school. Our findings suggest these encouraging changes may be the result of positively reinforcing individual processes, such as the positive associations between students? math and science motivation, as well as the support students receive. For example, we found that support from parents is important for students to maintain or develop more positive motivation during high school.

The second goal of the project was to examine how parents support students in STEM during high school. We found parent support is a consistent predictor of students? STEM motivation. The beliefs parents hold about STEM matter as we found that parents who believed boys are better at math than girls were more likely to have daughters with lower STEM identities. The STEM support parents provide, including talking to their children about STEM and initiating these conversations, is related to adolescents having stronger beliefs about their abilities in science. Parent support in high school was particularly important for students whose parents did not attend college or did not have a STEM career or college major.

Finally, we explored the extent to which students' STEM motivation was related to their STEM performance, STEM course choices in high school, or STEM college majors. We found that students who were held more positive motivational beliefs in STEM also performed better in  STEM courses, and were more likely to choose STEM activities in high school and STEM majors in college. These associations were similar across gender and college generation, suggesting that interventions on students? motivation might have similar impacts on all youth.

Drawing on motivation theories, sociological theories of social positioning, and feminist theories of intersectionality, the findings from this project addressed several critical gaps in the literature on STEM motivation among high school students, helped refine theories, and informed practice on STEM diversification. Our findings also call into question many long-held stereotypes about racial/ethnic groups and notions that parent support is of little consequence in high school. These results have been disseminated to academic audiences through 20 articles in high-impact journals. We have also presented our findings in 23 paper or poster conference presentations, including those for teachers, practitioners, and parents. In addition, the project provided students who are underrepresented in STEM with several opportunities to gain important skills for the next phase of their careers (e.g., grant writing, mentoring young scholars, benefits of qualitative and quantitative research methods) and to learn how to promote equity and diversity in STEM research.
